bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 164, Number 125 (Wednesday, July 25, 2018)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. BISHOP of Utah:H.R. 6510.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article IV, section 3, clause 2[Page H7687]

item.fullName: Del. Sablan, Gregorio Kilili Camacho [D-MP-At Large]
Del. Radewagen, Aumua Amata Coleman [R-AS-At Large]

item.title: H.R. 6510, Restore Our Parks and Public Lands Act

item.name: Wilderness and natural areas, wildlife refuges, wild rivers, habitats

item.text:
Restore Our Parks and Public Lands Act

This bill establishes the National Park Service and Public Lands Legacy Restoration Fund and requires 50% of all energy development revenues for FY2019-FY2023 to be deposited into such fund.

Amounts deposited in the fund must not exceed $1.3 billion for any fiscal year and must be used for meeting high-priority deferred maintenance needs of the National Park Service.
item.name: Introduced in House

bill.title: Restore Our Parks and Public Lands Act

item.title: To establish, fund, and provide for the use of amounts in a National Park Service and Public Lands Legacy Restoration Fund to address the maintenance backlog of the National Park Service, United States Fish and Wildlife Service, Bureau of Land Management, and Bureau of Indian Education, and for other purposes.
Restore Our Parks and Public Lands Act

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
